quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our wide-ranging conversation, we dig into strategies for building trust with people who are more experienced than you or older than you, we talk about coaching product managers, including why leading by example is often the most effective strategy, we talk about Asana's product development process and how it's evolved over the years as the company has scaled, plus some of Paige's product and career missteps, and what she's learned from those moments.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A compact preview of several actionable themes—trust-building, coaching via leading by example, scaling product process, and learning from missteps.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: To prep for this interview, I got input from some of Paige's colleagues and former colleagues, and everyone I talked to loved Paige.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical tactic (gathering 360° input) and underscores the reputational impact of strong cross-functional relationships.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: You might be building an incredible AI product, but if you're using the same data sets as your competitors to train your models, you don't have much of an advantage.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that differentiated data—not just models—can be the real moat in AI products.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Brave Search is the fastest growing search engine since Bing, and it's 100% independent from the big tech companies.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A specific data point and positioning claim relevant to teams evaluating search/data providers for product or AI use cases.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You might be building an incredible AI product, but if you're using the same data sets as your competitors to train your models, you don't have much of an advantage.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor
quotes.context: Highlights a practical competitive moat for AI products: differentiated training data.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Brave Search is the fastest growing search engine since Bing, and it's 100% independent from the big tech companies.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor
quotes.context: Provides a concrete positioning/data point about Brave’s growth and independence as an alternative search index.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're building products with search capabilities, you're probably experiencing soaring API costs or lack of viable global alternatives to Bing or Google.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor
quotes.context: Names two common, actionable pain points teams can validate when evaluating search infrastructure options.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Within minutes of connecting your email and calendar, you'll have a CRM that's already set up complete with customer profiles and automatic data enrichment.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor
quotes.context: Gives a specific implementation example of reducing CRM setup time via automated data ingestion and enrichment.

quotes.topic_title: Paige’s scope at Asana and core product
quotes.text: Effectively, our goal is to help teams work together more efficiently and drive the outcomes they're going for.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: A crisp product/strategy north star that practitioners can use to align teams on outcomes over output.

quotes.topic_title: Paige’s scope at Asana and core product
quotes.text: But really, we want to help people answer the question at work, "Who is doing what by when, and why?"
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: A memorable, reusable framing for diagnosing collaboration problems and defining what “clarity” means in a product or process.

quotes.topic_title: Paige’s scope at Asana and core product
quotes.text: So that notion of clarity of purpose, clarity of plan, progress, and responsibility are often so painful in people's work lives.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: A practical breakdown of “clarity” into four components teams can directly operationalize and measure.

quotes.topic_title: Paige’s scope at Asana and core product
quotes.text: When there is certainty there and clarity there, people can be much more efficient in getting the work done.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: A cause-and-effect claim that can guide prioritization: invest in clarity to unlock efficiency.

quotes.topic_title: How Asana’s planning and org structure evolved
quotes.text: So you can think of it as a nested structure around our product strategy as well as how we measure success.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: A clear mental model for aligning strategy and accountability via metrics at multiple organizational levels (pillar → area → team).

quotes.topic_title: How Asana’s planning and org structure evolved
quotes.text: Now, we plan every six months, but for a rolling 12 months. So we have higher confidence in the immediate half, lower confidence in the following half, but we just plan every 12 months, every six months because it gives our business more confidence in what's coming and a better opportunity to align our go-to-market and product planning.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: A practical planning cadence that balances adaptability with longer-term alignment across product and go-to-market.

quotes.topic_title: How Asana’s planning and org structure evolved
quotes.text: if you ask too much for a particular quarter, a particular week, or date, you will make strange choices about scope.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that over-precision in roadmaps can degrade decision-making and lead to poor scoping behavior.

quotes.topic_title: How Asana’s planning and org structure evolved
quotes.text: we added into our product process a notion that we might pivot or cut from stuff that we put on our roadmap because it felt like once it was on the roadmap, it had to be done, and that's just not smart.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: Actionable process guidance: explicitly normalize cutting/pivoting roadmap items to avoid commitment traps and improve outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: How Asana’s planning and org structure evolved
quotes.text: So we make sure that we understand what does good look like and what is a dynamic that we want to be creating in terms of people getting real value from using the product, and we build that into our metrics to have as a guardrail to ensure that we're not driving one metric at the expense of people really getting what they need out of Asana.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: A metrics design principle: define “healthy usage” guardrails so optimization doesn’t sacrifice real customer value.

quotes.topic_title: Double Diamond process and product reviews
quotes.text: So you go broad when you ask like, "What customer should I solve for?" and then you pick one, and then that's the narrowing. Then, you go broad, and you say, "What are the problems this customer has?" and you narrow, and you say, "This is the problem they have." Then, you go broad, and you say, "What solution should we do to this?" and then you go narrow, and you say, "This is the solution that we should start with."
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: A clear, repeatable broad-to-narrow sequence for customer → problem → solution decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Double Diamond process and product reviews
quotes.text: That process of going broad, and going narrow, and going broad, and going narrow forces people to get out of their opinion-driven lens because so often, we need to be curious quantitatively and qualitatively about what we're doing and why, and be more systematic and rigorous about getting there. It doesn't take long, but it just breaks the frame.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: Explains why the Double Diamond works: it reduces opinion-driven decisions by enforcing systematic inquiry.

quotes.topic_title: Double Diamond process and product reviews
quotes.text: It's really important because then you also know what success looks like because if you pick your success metrics as using a feature, that's it. You're teaching to the test. It's not actually driving the outcome.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: A contrarian warning against feature-usage metrics that incentivize the wrong outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Double Diamond process and product reviews
quotes.text: The inflection points are the kickoff, which is that going broad, and then customer and direction selection. So this is both the target as well as of the 10,000-foot views of how you might pursue solving this problem. Which path are you broadly going to take? Then, going broad within that path on different concepts, and then there's a design concept review. Then, the products spec. Then, the full experience review or design crit of the end-to-end experience and launch.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: Maps the Double Diamond to concrete review artifacts teams can implement (kickoff → direction → concept → spec → experience → launch).

quotes.topic_title: Asana hybrid work policy and office dynamics
quotes.text: So we're in the office Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, and then work from home mostly on Wednesdays and Fridays.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: A concrete hybrid schedule practitioners can benchmark against when designing office/remote rhythms.

quotes.topic_title: Asana hybrid work policy and office dynamics
quotes.text: It's bizarre that we could lose a muscle that we had that was so innate so quickly, and I think even in the last month, I would say, and it's in June of 2023, there's more vibrancy in the office, more conversation, more casual... someone eating alone at the cafeteria, and someone sitting down next to them. So it didn't happen overnight.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: Highlights that in-office collaboration habits atrophy and must be intentionally rebuilt over time rather than assumed to snap back.

quotes.topic_title: Asana hybrid work policy and office dynamics
quotes.text: I do think that having social casual relationships as well as more opportunities to talk strategy with people you're not forced into a meeting room with has been super beneficial.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: A practical rationale for office time: optimize for informal relationships and unscheduled strategy conversations.

quotes.topic_title: Asana hybrid work policy and office dynamics
quotes.text: I can say that just today, I was having lunch and sat down with my head of data science, and we had an impromptu chat about how we review our experiments and how to evaluate whether we had ROI on learning, not just the metrics.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: A specific example of serendipitous office interactions producing higher-quality decision-making (learning ROI vs. only metrics).

quotes.topic_title: Asana hybrid work policy and office dynamics
quotes.text: I would encourage you to know your chronotype and to lock that time where you have the most head space to do that work.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: Actionable deep-work advice: align your hardest work with your peak cognitive window.

quotes.topic_title: Building trust and projecting confidence as a leader
quotes.text: The thing I would say is bring the insight. Know thy customer. Know thy market. Know thy competitors. Know thy numbers. Know thy product.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable recipe for earning trust fast—out-preparing the room with customer/market/product mastery.

quotes.topic_title: Building trust and projecting confidence as a leader
quotes.text: But I think that's a really tricky and unique thing is not to pretend like you have more experience than you do, but to be willing to ask great questions, and then be curious enough that you're bringing insight to every meeting that people may or may not have, but you're always willing to share.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: A counterintuitive trust-builder: don’t posture—ask great questions and consistently contribute real insight.

quotes.topic_title: Building trust and projecting confidence as a leader
quotes.text: I don't know if you've heard about it, but she said that trust is equal to credibility plus reliability, plus authenticity, divided by or over perception of self-interest.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: A memorable “trust equation” framework leaders can use to diagnose and improve how they’re perceived.

quotes.topic_title: Building trust and projecting confidence as a leader
quotes.text: When you take a new role, become best friends with a researcher, and spend time watching customers use the product firsthand because what they maybe report on or are trying to do a study about might be very different from what you observe, but you really just need that front row seat with customers, and so asking, "How do I actually set up time with customers? How do I compensate them? How do I read the tickets?" Whatever.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: Highly actionable onboarding tactic: accelerate insight by direct customer observation and tight partnership with research.

quotes.topic_title: Building trust and projecting confidence as a leader
quotes.text: So real confidence is often conveyed by being willing to ask the question or to say, "I don't know what you mean by that. Can you say that again?"
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: Reframes confidence as clarity-seeking and vulnerability, not certainty or dominance in meetings.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Leading in tech is uniquely challenging, and doing it well is easiest when surrounded by leaders who understand your day-to-day experiences.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical leadership lever: improve performance by intentionally surrounding yourself with peers who share relevant context.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When we're meeting and building relationships with the right people, we're more likely to learn, find new opportunities, be dynamic in our thinking, and achieve our goals.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Offers an actionable mental model for networking as an input that compounds into learning, opportunity, and better thinking.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Building and managing your network doesn't have to feel like networking.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframe that encourages practitioners to approach networking as relationship-building rather than transactional outreach.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: One thing specifically that came up is that you're very big on leading and teaching by example, not just, "Here's how you do this thing."
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Surfaces a coaching methodology—model the behavior rather than only prescribing steps—that practitioners can apply in mentoring and management.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: So, if that's true, I'm curious where that came from for you and why you think that ends up being a lot more successful than like, "In a meeting, you should do X, Y, Z," versus doing it, and then letting them see.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Contrasts instruction vs. demonstration, pointing to an actionable teaching approach: show the behavior in real settings so others can observe and learn.

quotes.topic_title: Coaching PMs through leading by example
quotes.text: I remember hearing about a framework called the three Es: experience, exposure, and education.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable growth framework that expands beyond the typical “learn then do” career progression.

quotes.topic_title: Coaching PMs through leading by example
quotes.text: Exposure was such an important one where I thought like, "Okay. So you're not in the driver's seat, but you're in the car, and you hear what's happening, and you're evaluating how this is... what the impact is."
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: Defines “exposure” as a practical way to learn faster by observing real decision-making without owning the outcome.

quotes.topic_title: Coaching PMs through leading by example
quotes.text: So I'll give two examples. I mean, the way I run my meetings are the kind of meetings I want to be a part of.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: A concrete leading-by-example tactic: model the meeting behaviors you want your team to replicate.

quotes.topic_title: Coaching PMs through leading by example
quotes.text: Always answer the question that they should have asked.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: Counterintuitive communication advice for high-stakes settings: respond to the underlying strategic concern, not just the literal prompt.

quotes.topic_title: Career advice and conscious leadership mindset
quotes.text: So I really push people not to self-select, and I try to remind myself where that's appropriate to do the same thing.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: Actionable career advice to avoid disqualifying yourself prematurely and to apply even when you feel underqualified.

quotes.topic_title: Career advice and conscious leadership mindset
quotes.text: Other advice I often give is just think big, ship small. "Think big, ship small." What's the smallest thing you can do to do that thing?
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: A practical product/execution heuristic for maintaining ambition while delivering in small, shippable increments.

quotes.topic_title: Career advice and conscious leadership mindset
quotes.text: One of the things that you learn is to be above or below the line, and something that is this concept of like, "Where are you? Are you above the line? Are you below the line?" If you're above the line, you're committed to learning. You're open and curious. Things are funny here, more playful. If you're below the line, you're committed to winning. You're committed to being right. Things are more black and white.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: A clear mindset diagnostic that helps teams notice when they’re optimizing for learning vs. being right, and adjust behavior accordingly.

quotes.topic_title: Career advice and conscious leadership mindset
quotes.text: Then, I asked myself, "How might the opposite be true?" I was like, "I can do both." It was just enough to pop the balloon because sometimes your brain is so accustomed to having a scarcity mindset as opposed to creating alternative options or seeing a different path.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: A simple reframing question that interrupts scarcity thinking and opens up alternative options in high-stress moments.

quotes.topic_title: Career advice and conscious leadership mindset
quotes.text: I also had to be honest with people and say, "This is a 70% cut. 30% of this is missing or incorrect, and that's why I'm coming to you early."
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: A concrete example of using early, explicitly incomplete drafts to accelerate alignment and invite critique during planning.

quotes.topic_title: How Asana approaches AI and LLM product work
quotes.text: But when it came to the massive leap forward in LLMs recently, we staffed a team to really prototype quickly, and discover what was possible, and just apply hypotheses outside of the typical norms of how we work.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: A concrete resourcing model: create a dedicated rapid-prototyping team that operates outside normal process to explore LLM opportunities fast.

quotes.topic_title: How Asana approaches AI and LLM product work
quotes.text: So they went straight to prototyping instead of going through that Double Diamond I was explaining earlier.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: A counter-process methodology: bypass standard discovery frameworks to quickly validate feasibility and value with real prototypes.

quotes.topic_title: How Asana approaches AI and LLM product work
quotes.text: What that meant was that we were really quickly able to say, "Wow, this is just so much better than we imagined and would never have prioritized it because we thought it would take so much longer."
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: Highlights how prototyping can reveal underestimated ROI and overturn prioritization assumptions driven by perceived effort.

quotes.topic_title: How Asana approaches AI and LLM product work
quotes.text: So skipping a lot of that to just really try it on for a size has been key, and then what we're doing is giving the teams with the most expertise in the customer problems. For example, status and progress reporting, the keys to that car and saying like, "Here's the starter. Here's the hypothesis. Here's how far we got with it. It's dogfooding. What do you want to do?"
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: A scalable handoff pattern: central team produces a dogfooded starter + hypothesis, then domain teams take ownership to scale within their problem area.

quotes.topic_title: Intuit training lessons: customer focus and feedback
quotes.text: How do you actually watch customers using your product or just doing the things they do, collecting the artifacts, knowing the workarounds, and using that experience to build opportunities for surprise and insight that then you can capitalize and create products around?
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable approach to customer-centric product discovery rooted in direct observation and artifact collection.

quotes.topic_title: Intuit training lessons: customer focus and feedback
quotes.text: So delivering feedback is something that I think everyone benefits from, but for managers, it's so much more critical because if you don't do it, and you don't say what you mean, and you don't do it in a way that it can be internalized and acted upon, you really don't set up your teammates, your teams for growth or success in their careers.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: Highlights the managerial obligation to make feedback actionable and explicit to enable growth.

quotes.topic_title: Intuit training lessons: customer focus and feedback
quotes.text: Okay. I'm going to convey this feedback as situation, behavior, impact. The situation is on Tuesday in that meeting at 3:00. Behavior, you interrupted me while I was saying this thing. Impact, made me feel like you weren't listening to me or made me feel like your voice was more important than mine, or impact, blah, blah, blah.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: Provides the SBI (situation-behavior-impact) model with a specific example practitioners can copy for delivering feedback.

quotes.topic_title: Intuit training lessons: customer focus and feedback
quotes.text: It doesn't matter what the impact is because the way you've set it up is it's a subjective observation. It's not what the camera recorded, it's what you experienced. Therefore, it is true and valuable feedback, and it gets the conversation started such that you can then talk about next steps.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframing that legitimizes subjective impact as valid feedback and unlocks forward-looking discussion.

quotes.topic_title: Intuit training lessons: customer focus and feedback
quotes.text: That format and framing really helped me understand that delivering feedback isn't about being right or about getting the right information to the other person. It's about sharing the impact of different decisions that they're making.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: Reorients feedback from correctness to impact-sharing, making it easier to deliver and easier to receive.

quotes.topic_title: What holds back new PMs and how to succeed
quotes.text: I would say this illusion that you have to be all-knowing and super confident sets you up to be in a place of advocacy instead of inquiry.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: Reframes early-PM confidence as a trap that shifts you from learning to pushing solutions.

quotes.topic_title: What holds back new PMs and how to succeed
quotes.text: What pro means is trying to cut that straight path, and that can reduce information and conversation that makes you smarter.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: Challenges the “move fast” instinct by highlighting how skipping steps reduces learning and decision quality.

quotes.topic_title: What holds back new PMs and how to succeed
quotes.text: So I would say something that really holds PMs back is not being collaborative from a place of true curiosity like performative collaboration where they're not in a room or want to do a review, but ultimately, they don't really want the questions or the feedback.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: Names a common failure mode—going through the motions of collaboration without genuinely inviting critique.

quotes.topic_title: What holds back new PMs and how to succeed
quotes.text: You can ask clarifying questions. You can ask the question behind the question. You can hear the feedback, and then say, "Was that something that I must do, that I should do, or that I should consider?"
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: Provides a practical questioning and prioritization method for turning feedback into actionable decisions.

quotes.topic_title: What holds back new PMs and how to succeed
quotes.text: You don't need to ask for a promotion. Your outcomes should speak for themselves.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: Counterintuitive career advice: focus on outcomes and the work, and advocacy will follow.

quotes.topic_title: Early management missteps: avoiding micromanagement
quotes.text: So I would say one of the missteps here is knowing how to give guidance or direction in a way that doesn't feel like micromanagement because what you're trying to do is to teach a repeatable pattern instead of giving a precise instruction that can be used once, and then disposed of.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: A clear mental model for avoiding micromanagement: focus on teaching reusable patterns rather than one-off instructions.

quotes.topic_title: Early management missteps: avoiding micromanagement
quotes.text: So, for example, I would go to my meetings with a stack of Post-Its, and I would write what I wish I was saying on Post-Its and see if someone else would say it first.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: A concrete self-management tactic to create space for others to lead and contribute before the manager speaks.

quotes.topic_title: Early management missteps: avoiding micromanagement
quotes.text: But you've got to police yourself because no one else will do it because no matter how accessible you think you are, other people know that you're the boss.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that power dynamics persist even with approachable leaders, so restraint must be self-imposed.

quotes.topic_title: Early management missteps: avoiding micromanagement
quotes.text: Something I realized was that I had an experience where I didn't realize that people didn't think I was being authentic because they thought something was bad, and I wasn't talking about it, but it wasn't because I didn't think it was bad or didn't see.
quotes.speaker: Paige Costello
quotes.context: Highlights the risk that positivity can be misread as inauthenticity if leaders don’t explicitly acknowledge problems.
